#' Specify a secondary axis
#'
#' This function is used in conjunction with a position scale to create a
#' secondary axis, positioned opposite of the primary axis. All secondary
#' axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
#'
#' @param transform A formula or function of a strictly monotonic transformation
#'
#' @param trans `r lifecycle::badge("deprecated")`
#'
#' @param name The name of the secondary axis
#'
#' @param breaks One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no breaks
#'   - `waiver()` for the default breaks computed by the transformation object
#'   - A numeric vector of positions
#'   - A function that takes the limits as input and returns breaks as output
#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}
#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
dup_axis <- function(transform = identity, name = derive(), breaks = derive(),
                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {
  sec_axis(transform, trans = trans, name, breaks, labels, guide)
}

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
derive <- function() {
  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}
is.derived <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "derived")
}
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)

#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}
#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
dup_axis <- function(transform = identity, name = derive(), breaks = derive(),
                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {
  sec_axis(transform, trans = trans, name, breaks, labels, guide)
}

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
derive <- function() {
  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}
is.derived <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "derived")
}
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.
samples.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

content.text:
# Finding the tailnum with highest proportion of NA arr_delays (min 100 flights)

I'll solve this by:
1. Grouping by tailnum
2. Calculating the proportion of NA arr_delays for each plane
3. Filtering for planes with at least 100 flights
4. Finding the one with the highest NA proportion

```r
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    proportion_na = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  arrange(desc(proportion_na)) %>%
  slice(1) %>%
  pull(tailnum)
```

This code:
- Groups the flights by tailnum
- For each tailnum, calculates:
  - Total number of flights
  - Number of flights with missing arrival delays
  - Proportion of flights with missing arrival delays
- Filters to only include planes with at least 100 flights
- Sorts in descending order by the proportion of NA values
- Takes the first row (highest proportion)
- Returns just the tailnum value

The criterion specifies a particular approach with three main steps:

3. Finally arrange in descending order

events.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

content.text:
# Finding tailnum with highest proportion of NA arr_delays (with at least 100 flights)

I'll approach this systematically using the tidyverse to analyze the flight data:

```r
flights %>%
  # Group by tailnum to analyze each plane separately
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  # Calculate total flights and proportion of NA arr_delays for each tailnum
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    prop_na = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  # Filter for planes with at least 100 flights
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  # Order by highest proportion of NAs
  arrange(desc(prop_na)) %>%
  # Take the top result
  slice(1) %>%
  # Extract just the tailnum
  pull(tailnum)
```

This code:
1. Groups the flight data by tailnum (each individual aircraft)
2. For each aircraft, calculates:
   - Total number of flights
   - Number of flights with missing arrival delay data
   - Proportion of flights with missing arrival delay data
3. Keeps only aircraft that have flown at least 100 flights
4. Orders them by the proportion of missing data (highest first)
5. Selects the aircraft with the highest proportion
6. Returns just the tailnum of that aircraft

This gives us the tailnum that, among planes with at least 100 flights, has the highest percentage of missing arrival delay information.

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.
***
[Submission]: # Finding tailnum with highest proportion of NA arr_delays (with at least 100 flights)

I'll approach this systematically using the tidyverse to analyze the flight data:

```r
flights %>%
  # Group by tailnum to analyze each plane separately
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  # Calculate total flights and proportion of NA arr_delays for each tailnum
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    prop_na = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  # Filter for planes with at least 100 flights
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  # Order by highest proportion of NAs
  arrange(desc(prop_na)) %>%
  # Take the top result
  slice(1) %>%
  # Extract just the tailnum
  pull(tailnum)
```

This code:
1. Groups the flight data by tailnum (each individual aircraft)
2. For each aircraft, calculates:
   - Total number of flights
   - Number of flights with missing arrival delay data
   - Proportion of flights with missing arrival delay data
3. Keeps only aircraft that have flown at least 100 flights
4. Orders them by the proportion of missing data (highest first)
5. Selects the aircraft with the highest proportion
6. Returns just the tailnum of that aircraft

This gives us the tailnum that, among planes with at least 100 flights, has the highest percentage of missing arrival delay information.
***
[Criterion]: There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

I'll evaluate this submission against the criterion for finding the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s among those with at least 100 flights.

2. Then calculate the proportion of NA values using `mean(is.na(arr_delay))`
3. Finally arrange in descending order

```r
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    prop_na = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  arrange(desc(prop_na)) %>%
  slice(1) %>%
  pull(tailnum)
```

- First summarizes all `tailnum`s to calculate flight counts
- Then filters for those with at least 100 flights
- Instead of using `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` it calculates the proportion as `sum(is.na(arr_delay))/total_flights`

1. The order of operations is different (summarize then filter vs. filter while grouped)
2. The threshold is >= 100 instead of > 100
3. Uses sum/total instead of mean for the proportion calculation

While mathematically `sum(is.na(arr_delay))/total_flights` is equivalent to `mean(is.na(arr_delay))`, the approach is different from what the criterion specifies. The general logic is correct, but the implementation doesn't follow the required steps.

GRADE: P

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

# Finding tailnum with highest proportion of NA arr_delays (with at least 100 flights)

I'll approach this systematically using the tidyverse to analyze the flight data:

```r
flights %>%
  # Group by tailnum to analyze each plane separately
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  # Calculate total flights and proportion of NA arr_delays for each tailnum
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    prop_na = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  # Filter for planes with at least 100 flights
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  # Order by highest proportion of NAs
  arrange(desc(prop_na)) %>%
  # Take the top result
  slice(1) %>%
  # Extract just the tailnum
  pull(tailnum)
```

This code:
1. Groups the flight data by tailnum (each individual aircraft)
2. For each aircraft, calculates:
   - Total number of flights
   - Number of flights with missing arrival delay data
   - Proportion of flights with missing arrival delay data
3. Keeps only aircraft that have flown at least 100 flights
4. Orders them by the proportion of missing data (highest first)
5. Selects the aircraft with the highest proportion
6. Returns just the tailnum of that aircraft

This gives us the tailnum that, among planes with at least 100 flights, has the highest percentage of missing arrival delay information.

events.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

content.text:
To find the tailnum with the highest proportion of NA arrival delays among those with at least 100 flights, I'll:

1. Group the data by tailnum
2. Calculate the total flights and proportion of NA arrival delays for each aircraft
3. Filter for those with at least 100 flights
4. Find the one with the highest NA proportion

```r
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    proportion_na = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  arrange(desc(proportion_na)) %>%
  slice(1) %>%
  pull(tailnum)
```

This code:
- Groups flights by aircraft (tailnum)
- Counts total flights and calculates the proportion of missing arrival delays
- Keeps only aircraft with 100+ flights
- Sorts by the NA proportion in descending order
- Takes the top result
- Returns just the tailnum with the highest proportion of missing arrival delays

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.
***
[Submission]: To find the tailnum with the highest proportion of NA arrival delays among those with at least 100 flights, I'll:

1. Group the data by tailnum
2. Calculate the total flights and proportion of NA arrival delays for each aircraft
3. Filter for those with at least 100 flights
4. Find the one with the highest NA proportion

```r
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    proportion_na = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  arrange(desc(proportion_na)) %>%
  slice(1) %>%
  pull(tailnum)
```

This code:
- Groups flights by aircraft (tailnum)
- Counts total flights and calculates the proportion of missing arrival delays
- Keeps only aircraft with 100+ flights
- Sorts by the NA proportion in descending order
- Takes the top result
- Returns just the tailnum with the highest proportion of missing arrival delays
***
[Criterion]: There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.
***
[END DATA]

I'll evaluate the submitted answer against the criterion for finding the tailnum with the highest proportion of NA arr_delays.

The criterion specifies three main steps should be followed:
1. First filter groups to only include tailnums with >100 flights
2. Then summarize to calculate the proportion of NA arr_delays using mean(is.na(arr_delay))
3. Finally, arrange in descending order of this proportion

The submitted answer takes a different approach:
```r
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    proportion_na = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  arrange(desc(proportion_na)) %>%
  slice(1) %>%
  pull(tailnum)
```

Key differences:
- It summarizes first, then filters, rather than filtering first (violating the criterion's specification that "no persistent summarization across rows should happen" in step 1)
- It calculates the proportion using sum(is.na(arr_delay))/total_flights instead of mean(is.na(arr_delay))
- While mathematically equivalent, the criterion specifically states that mean(is.na(arr_delay)) should be used

Although the code would produce the correct result, it doesn't follow the required approach specified in the criterion. The order of operations (filter-then-summarize vs. summarize-then-filter) is an important distinction in data processing pipelines.

GRADE: P

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

To find the tailnum with the highest proportion of NA arrival delays among those with at least 100 flights, I'll:

1. Group the data by tailnum
2. Calculate the total flights and proportion of NA arrival delays for each aircraft
3. Filter for those with at least 100 flights
4. Find the one with the highest NA proportion

```r
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    proportion_na = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  arrange(desc(proportion_na)) %>%
  slice(1) %>%
  pull(tailnum)
```

This code:
- Groups flights by aircraft (tailnum)
- Counts total flights and calculates the proportion of missing arrival delays
- Keeps only aircraft with 100+ flights
- Sorts by the NA proportion in descending order
- Takes the top result
- Returns just the tailnum with the highest proportion of missing arrival delays

events.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

content.text:
# Using `by` Argument in `mutate()` Function

The error occurs because you're trying to use the `by` argument incorrectly within the `mutate()` function. This is likely happening in one of two ways:

## Problem 1: Incorrect Placement

You might be using `by` as a column to create rather than as an argument to `mutate()`:

```r
# INCORRECT
df %>% 
  mutate(by = c(id, date))
```

## Problem 2: Incorrect Syntax

If you're using dplyr 1.1.0 or newer, the correct syntax for using `by` is:

```r
# CORRECT - newer dplyr (>= 1.1.0)
df %>% 
  mutate(new_column = some_calculation, .by = c(id, date))
```

## Solutions

### Option 1: Use correct `.by` syntax (dplyr >= 1.1.0)
```r
df %>% 
  mutate(your_calculation_here, .by = c(id, date))
```

### Option 2: Use `group_by()` instead (all dplyr versions)
```r
df %>% 
  group_by(id, date) %>%
  mutate(your_calculation_here) %>%
  ungroup()
```

The error message indicates that you have 2,909,492 rows in your dataset, but your `by` specification is creating a vector of 5,818,984 elements (twice the size), suggesting you're not using the `.by` argument correctly.

Would you like to share your actual code so I can give you more specific advice?

# CORRECT - newer dplyr (>= 1.1.0)
df %>%

df %>%

df %>%

content.text:
# Fixing `.by` Error in `mutate()`

The error you're encountering suggests you're not using the `.by` parameter correctly within the `mutate()` function. This is likely happening because you're using `by = c(id, date)` instead of the correct syntax.

## Solution

In dplyr 1.1.0 and later, the correct way to use the `.by` parameter in `mutate()` is:

```r
# CORRECT: Using .by with a dot prefix
data %>%
  mutate(new_column = some_calculation, .by = c(id, date))
```

Or using quoted column names:

```r
data %>%
  mutate(new_column = some_calculation, .by = c("id", "date"))
```

## Common mistakes to avoid:

1. Missing the dot prefix (should be `.by`, not `by`)
2. Putting `.by` inside the calculation instead of as a separate parameter
3. Using unquoted variable names without `c()` or quoted names with `c()`

## Alternative approach:

You can also use `group_by()` before `mutate()`:

```r
data %>%
  group_by(id, date) %>%
  mutate(new_column = some_calculation) %>%
  ungroup()  # Don't forget to ungroup after if needed
```

This error occurs because R is evaluating `c(id, date)` as the actual column values (creating a vector twice as large as your dataset) rather than as column names to group by.

messages.content:
I get an error using `.by` inside `mutate()`

```
Error in `mutate()`:
 In argument: `by = c(id, date)`.
Caused by error:
! `by` must be size 2909492 or 1, not 5818984.
```

How do I fix it?

content.text:
# Error Using `.by` Inside `mutate()`

The error you're seeing occurs because you're using the `.by` argument incorrectly within the `mutate()` function. It looks like you've included it as if it were a column to create rather than as a parameter to the function.

## The Fix

The `.by` parameter should be placed at the function level, not as a column definition:

### Incorrect usage:
```r
df %>% 
  mutate(
    new_column = some_calculation,
    by = c(id, date)  # WRONG - no dot prefix and inside the column definitions
  )
```

### Correct usage:
```r
df %>% 
  mutate(
    new_column = some_calculation,
    .by = c(id, date)  # RIGHT - with dot prefix and as a function parameter
  )
```

Or alternatively, if you're using dplyr >= 1.1.0:
```r
df %>% 
  mutate(
    new_column = some_calculation,
    .by = c("id", "date")  # Also works with strings
  )
```

## Alternative approach
If you're using an older version of dplyr that doesn't support `.by`, use `group_by()`:

```r
df %>%
  group_by(id, date) %>%
  mutate(new_column = some_calculation) %>%
  ungroup()
```

Does this fix your issue?

content.text:
I'll add the `name` parameter to the `task_create` function that defaults to the name of the dataset argument in the calling environment, and then store it as an attribute in the returned object.

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),  # Default to name in calling env
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "dir") <- dir
  attr(res, "name") <- name  # Store the name as an attribute

  res
}
```

This implementation:
1. Adds a `name` parameter after `dataset`
2. Uses `deparse(substitute(dataset))` to get the name of the dataset object in the calling environment
3. Stores the name as an attribute in the result object

With this change, when a user calls:
```r
x <- task_create(dataset = eval)
```

`attr(x, "name")` will contain `"eval"`.

If the user wants to specify a different name, they can do so explicitly:
```r
x <- task_create(dataset = eval, name = "my_custom_name")
```

events.target:
```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  force(name)
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "name") <- name
  attr(res, "dir") <- dir

  res
}
```

Notably:

* `name` should default to `deparse(substitute(dataset))` or something similar
* `name` needs be `force()`d, or somehow evaluated, before `check_dataset(dataset)` so that the substitution works correctly.
* At some point, the `name` attribute is set to the value.
* The rest of the function should be unaffected, e.g. no comments added to code that existed already.

I'll modify the function to add a `name` parameter that defaults to the name of the dataset object in the calling environment, and store it as an attribute in the result:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {

}
```

With this change, when you call the function as in your example:

```r
x <- task_create(dataset = eval)
```

The `name` parameter will default to `"eval"` (the name of the dataset object), and this will be stored as an attribute in the returned object, which you can access with `attr(x, "name")`.

task_create <- function(
    dataset,

) {

    structure(
      dataset,

    )
    
  attr(res, "dir") <- dir
  attr(res, "name") <- name
  
  res
}

The most significant omission is the lack of `force(name)` which is required to ensure proper evaluation of the name parameter. This is a critical part of the criterion.

GRADE: P

task_create <- function(
    dataset,

    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "dir") <- dir
  attr(res, "name") <- name  # Store the name as an attribute

  res
}
```

This modification adds the `name` parameter with a default value of `deparse(substitute(dataset))`, which extracts the variable name used for the dataset argument. The function then stores this name as an attribute in the returned object.

Now when someone calls `x <- task_create(dataset = eval)`, the `attr(x, "name")` will be "eval".

messages.content: How do I jitter points with ggplot2 only with respect to the x axis, leaving the y values unchanged?

content.text:
# Jittering Points Only on X-Axis in ggplot2

To jitter points only along the x-axis in ggplot2 while keeping the y values unchanged, you can use `geom_jitter()` with the `height` parameter set to 0:

```r
library(ggplot2)

ggplot(data = your_data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)
```

Alternatively, you can use `geom_point()` with the `position_jitter()` function:

```r
ggplot(data = your_data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```

In both cases:
- `width = 0.2` controls the amount of horizontal jitter (adjust as needed)
- `height = 0` ensures no vertical jitter

This approach is useful when you have categorical x-values and want to see the distribution of points without changing their y-values.

content.text:
# Jittering Points Horizontally Only in ggplot2

To jitter points in ggplot2 only along the x-axis while keeping y values unchanged, you can use either `geom_jitter()` or `geom_point()` with `position_jitter()` and set the `height` parameter to 0:

```r
# Option 1: Using geom_jitter directly
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)

# Option 2: Using geom_point with position_jitter
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```

## Key Parameters:
- `width`: Controls the amount of horizontal jitter (adjust as needed)
- `height = 0`: Ensures no vertical jittering occurs

This approach is particularly useful for categorical x variables when you want to avoid overlapping points while maintaining the exact y values for precision.

# Jittering Points Horizontally Only in ggplot2

This approach is particularly useful for categorical x variables when you want to avoid overlapping points while maintaining the exact y values for precision.

messages.content: How do I jitter points with ggplot2 only with respect to the x axis, leaving the y values unchanged?

content.text:
# Jittering Points Along X-Axis Only in ggplot2

To jitter points only along the x-axis while keeping y values intact, you can use either `geom_jitter()` or `position_jitter()` with the height parameter set to 0:

## Method 1: Using geom_jitter()

```r
library(ggplot2)

ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0) +
  # add other plot elements
  theme_minimal()
```

## Method 2: Using position_jitter() with geom_point()

```r
library(ggplot2)

ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)) +
  # add other plot elements
  theme_minimal()
```

## Complete Example

```r
library(ggplot2)

# Sample data
set.seed(123)
df <- data.frame(
  category = rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each = 20),
  value = c(rnorm(20, 10, 1), rnorm(20, 12, 1), rnorm(20, 14, 1))
)

# Plot with x-axis jitter only
ggplot(df, aes(x = category, y = value)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0, alpha = 0.7) +
  labs(title = "Points jittered only horizontally",
       x = "Category", y = "Value") +
  theme_minimal()
```

The key is setting `height = 0` while giving `width` a positive value to control the amount of horizontal jittering.

# Jittering Points Along X-Axis Only in ggplot2

To jitter points only along the x-axis while keeping y values intact, you can use either `geom_jitter()` or `position_jitter()` with the height parameter set to 0:

## Method 1: Using geom_jitter()

```r

ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0) +
  # add other plot elements
  theme_minimal()
```

## Method 2: Using position_jitter() with geom_point()

```r
library(ggplot2)

ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)) +
  # add other plot elements
  theme_minimal()
```

## Complete Example

```r
library(ggplot2)

# Sample data
set.seed(123)
df <- data.frame(
  category = rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each = 20),
  value = c(rnorm(20, 10, 1), rnorm(20, 12, 1), rnorm(20, 14, 1))
)

# Plot with x-axis jitter only
ggplot(df, aes(x = category, y = value)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0, alpha = 0.7) +
  labs(title = "Points jittered only horizontally",
       x = "Category", y = "Value") +
  theme_minimal()
```

The key is setting `height = 0` while giving `width` a positive value to control the amount of horizontal jittering.

samples.input:
I have some code

```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
...
}
```

I'd like the default name to be the symbol referring to the dataset, e.g. in

```
simple_addition <- tibble(
  input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"),
  target = c("4", "5")
)

tsk <- 
  task_create(
    dataset = simple_addition
  )
```

...the name would be "simple_addition". Instead, it's substituted to `structure(list(input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"), target = c("4", , "5"), id = 1:2), row.names = c(NA, -2L), class = c("tbl_df", , and "tbl", "data.frame"))`. How can I fix that?
samples.target: The `name` default is evaluated lazily, and something else results in `dataset` being evaluated before `name` is. `name` must be evaluated early in the function, e.g. using `force(name)`.

content.text:
# Fixing Variable Name Capture in R Function

The issue you're encountering is that `deparse(substitute(dataset))` isn't capturing the variable name as expected because of how evaluation happens in your function.

## Solution: Use `rlang` for Proper Quoting

The most reliable solution is to use the `rlang` package, which is designed to handle these non-standard evaluation cases correctly:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = rlang::as_name(rlang::enquo(dataset)),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
  # Function body...
}
```

## Alternative Base R Solution

If you prefer to avoid adding a dependency, you can modify your function to capture the expression before evaluation:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
    if (is.null(name)) {
        name <- deparse(substitute(dataset))
    }
    # Rest of function...
}
```

## Why This Is Happening

The issue occurs because:
1. When you call the function, R evaluates the `dataset` argument before the function body executes
2. By the time `deparse(substitute(dataset))` runs, it's working with the evaluated tibble, not the variable name

Both solutions above capture the unevaluated expression (the variable name) before it gets replaced with its value.

With either solution, your example will correctly use "simple_addition" as the name.

I need to assess whether this submission correctly addresses the issue according to the specified criterion.

The criterion states that the problem is due to lazy evaluation of the `name` parameter, and the solution should involve evaluating `name` early in the function using something like `force(name)`.

Let's analyze the submission:

1. First solution using `rlang`:
```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = rlang::as_name(rlang::enquo(dataset)),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
  # Function body...
}
```

2. Second solution using base R:
```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
    if (is.null(name)) {
        name <- deparse(substitute(dataset))
    }
    # Rest of function...
}
```

While the submission correctly identifies that there's an issue with evaluation timing, neither solution implements the specific approach mentioned in the criterion - using `force(name)` to ensure early evaluation of the parameter.

The `rlang` solution attempts to capture the unevaluated expression, but doesn't address the lazy evaluation problem as specified.

The base R solution changes the API (by making `name = NULL` the default) and computes the name inside the function body, which is conceptually different from forcing early evaluation of the existing parameter.

Neither solution implements the specific requirement to force early evaluation of the parameter while maintaining the original function signature.

GRADE: I

) {

}

The issue you're encountering is that `deparse(substitute(dataset))` isn't capturing the variable name as expected because of how evaluation happens in your function.

## Solution: Use `rlang` for Proper Quoting

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = rlang::as_name(rlang::enquo(dataset)),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
  # Function body...
}

```r
task_create <- function(

    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {

}

content.text:
# Fixing the Variable Name in Function Arguments

The issue is that `deparse(substitute(dataset))` is capturing the entire structure of your tibble rather than just the variable name. This happens because your tibble is being evaluated before it's passed to `deparse(substitute())`.

## Solution

To properly capture the variable name, change your function definition to:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = as.character(substitute(dataset)),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
  # ...function body...
}
```

The key change is using `as.character(substitute(dataset))` instead of `deparse(substitute(dataset))`. This will directly convert the symbol to a character string without trying to deparse the entire object structure.

## Why This Works

- `substitute(dataset)` captures the unevaluated expression passed to `dataset`
- `as.character()` directly converts the symbol to a character string
- This approach works when you pass a simple variable name like `simple_addition`

## Alternative (for newer R versions)

If you're using a newer version of R, you can also use `deparse1()`:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse1(substitute(dataset)),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
  # ...
}
```

Now when you run:
```r
tsk <- task_create(dataset = simple_addition)
```

The `name` parameter will correctly be set to "simple_addition".

content.text:
# Fixing the Default Name Parameter Issue

The problem is that `deparse(substitute(dataset))` isn't working as expected because the evaluation is happening in a way that captures the entire data structure rather than the variable name.

## Solution

Use `match.call()` instead, which will capture the actual function call and allow you to extract the expression used for the `dataset` argument:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = as.character(match.call()$dataset),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
  # Rest of your function...
}
```

With this change, when you call:

```r
simple_addition <- tibble(
  input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"),
  target = c("4", "5")
)

tsk <- task_create(dataset = simple_addition)
```

The `name` parameter will correctly be set to `"simple_addition"`.

## Why This Works

`match.call()` returns the actual call used to invoke the function, preserving the original expressions before they're evaluated. Then `$dataset` extracts just the expression used for the dataset argument, and `as.character()` converts that expression to a string.

## Alternative Solution

If you prefer keeping a similar approach to your original code, you could also try:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
    if(is.null(name)) {
        # Get the name at the top of the function
        name <- deparse(substitute(dataset))
    }
    # Rest of your function...
}
```

This sometimes works better because it evaluates `substitute(dataset)` immediately at the start of the function.

2. Something else results in `dataset` being evaluated before `name` is
3. `name` must be evaluated early in the function using `force(name)` or similar

Let's examine the submission:

The first solution changes the default value to `name = as.character(match.call()$dataset)`. While this approach might work functionally, it doesn't address the actual evaluation order issue identified in the criterion. It changes the method of getting the name rather than fixing the evaluation order problem.

The second solution uses `name = NULL` with a conditional check in the function body. Again, this doesn't directly address the lazy evaluation problem as specified in the criterion.

Neither solution implements the required fix, which would be to use `force(name)` at the beginning of the function while keeping the original default value approach. The submission doesn't recognize that the issue is about evaluation order that could be fixed with `force()`.

A correct solution would have maintained the original default value and added `force(name)` at the beginning of the function:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
    force(name)  # Force immediate evaluation of name
    # Rest of function...
}
```

Since the submission doesn't meet the specific criterion of using `force(name)` to ensure early evaluation, I must rate it as incorrect.

GRADE: I

- It clearly explains that when generating UI elements dynamically within a server function, careful namespace handling is needed

samples.input:
I have an R package that depends on a package called, lets say, spatialstuff (This is how it is defined in its DESCRIPTIONS). However it is found in an org and the repo name is different, eg org/spatial-Stuff (i have no control over this name!).

My package in its `DESCRIPTION` file has the following lines

```
Imports:
 spatialstuff
Remotes:
 org/spatial-Stuff
```

However the `pkgdown.yaml` workflow that is run upon pushes (created from `usethis::use_pkgdown_github_pages()`) errors with the following message.

Can someone explain if this is user error or some other error? Thanks

```
! error in pak subprocess
Caused by error:
! Could not solve package dependencies:
deps::.: Can't install dependency spatialstuff
* spatialstuff: Can't find package called spatialstuff.
* local::.: Can't install dependency spatialstuff
* any::sessioninfo: dependency conflict
* any::pkgdown: dependency conflict
```
samples.target: The user needs to specify the package name explicitly in the Remotes `DESCRIPTION` field using a `<package>=` prefix, e.g. `spatialstuff=org/spatial-Stuff`.

content.text:
# Understanding the Dependency Issue

This looks like a common issue with package names in GitHub repositories versus the actual R package name. Let's clarify what's happening:

## The Problem

Your package requires a dependency called `spatialstuff`, but the GitHub repository name for this package is `org/spatial-Stuff`. The package manager (`pak`) is having trouble resolving this dependency during the pkgdown build process.

## Likely Causes

1. **Package name mismatch**: The R package name inside the `org/spatial-Stuff` repository (as defined in its DESCRIPTION file) might not actually be `spatialstuff`.

2. **Remotes specification issue**: The way you've specified the remote might need adjustment.

## Solutions to Try

1. **Verify the actual package name**:
   - Check the DESCRIPTION file in the `org/spatial-Stuff` repository 
   - Look for the `Package:` field to confirm the actual R package name

2. **Adjust your Remotes specification**:
   ```
   Remotes:
     github::org/spatial-Stuff
   ```

3. **If the actual package name differs**, update your Imports section to match it:
   ```
   Imports:
     actual_package_name
   Remotes:
     github::org/spatial-Stuff
   ```

4. **For pkgdown specifically**, modify your GitHub workflow file to install the dependency explicitly before building the site:
   ```yaml
   - name: Install dependencies
     run: |
       remotes::install_github("org/spatial-Stuff")
     shell: Rscript {0}
   ```

This is most likely a package name mismatch issue rather than user error - the R package name inside the GitHub repository probably doesn't match what you've specified in your Imports.

content.text:
# R Package Dependency Resolution Issue

The error you're seeing is due to a mismatch between the package name (`spatialstuff`) and how it's being resolved from the GitHub repository (`org/spatial-Stuff`).

## The Problem

When the pkgdown GitHub Action runs, it's trying to install all dependencies, but it can't find a package named "spatialstuff" when looking at the GitHub repository "org/spatial-Stuff". This typically happens when:

1. The package name in the actual repository's DESCRIPTION file doesn't match what you're importing
2. The GitHub repository structure doesn't contain a valid R package in the expected location

## Solution

Try modifying your `Remotes:` section to explicitly map the package name to the repository:

```
Remotes:
  spatialstuff=org/spatial-Stuff
```

This explicit mapping tells R that the package named "spatialstuff" should be fetched from the GitHub repository "org/spatial-Stuff".

## Other Troubleshooting Steps

If that doesn't work:

1. **Verify the actual package name**: Check the DESCRIPTION file in the org/spatial-Stuff repository to confirm the exact package name (the `Package:` field)

2. **Check the repository structure**: Ensure the repository has a standard R package structure with the DESCRIPTION file at the root

3. **Consider using a specific branch or commit**:
   ```
   Remotes:
     spatialstuff=org/spatial-Stuff@main
   ```

4. **Check case sensitivity**: R package names are case-sensitive, so make sure the capitalization matches

This is a common issue when working with GitHub-hosted packages where the repository name differs from the R package name.

content.text:
# R Package Dependency Issue Analysis

The issue you're encountering is likely due to a mismatch between how the package is identified in your `DESCRIPTION` file and how GitHub/pak resolves it.

## The Problem

When installing packages with remotes specified in GitHub format, the system needs to:
1. Find the GitHub repository
2. Install the package
3. Register it under the correct package name

## What's Happening

The error shows that the system can't find `spatialstuff` despite your `Remotes` specification. This typically occurs because:

- The package name in the remote repository's DESCRIPTION file doesn't match what you've specified in your `Imports`
- The GitHub Actions environment is having trouble resolving the GitHub remote

## Possible Solutions

1. **Check package name consistency**:
   Verify that the package in `org/spatial-Stuff` has `Package: spatialstuff` in its DESCRIPTION file.

2. **Use a more explicit Remotes specification**:
   ```
   Remotes:
     spatialstuff=org/spatial-Stuff
   ```
   This explicitly tells R which package name corresponds to which repository.

3. **Try an alternative format**:
   ```
   Remotes:
     github::org/spatial-Stuff
   ```
   
4. **Try directly using `pak` syntax**:
   ```
   Remotes:
     org/spatial-Stuff@main
   ```

This is most likely a configuration issue rather than a bug in any of the tools. The package dependency resolver needs to clearly understand the mapping between the package name in `Imports` and the GitHub repository.

Would you like me to explain more about one of these potential solutions?

content.text:
# Fixing Recursive Default Argument Error

The error you're seeing is caused by a naming conflict in your function parameters. When you have a parameter with the same name as a variable from the enclosing environment (in this case, both named `chat`), R gets confused about which one you're referring to when setting the default value.

## Solution

Here's the fixed version:

```r
generate <- function(outer_chat = ellmer::chat_claude()) {
  
  function(input, chat = outer_chat) {
    ch <- chat$clone()
    res <- ch$chat(input)
    list(result = res, chat = ch)
  }
}
```

## What Changed

1. Renamed the parameter in the outer function to `outer_chat`
2. Used this differently-named variable as the default value for the inner function's `chat` parameter

This avoids the recursive reference problem because now there's no ambiguity between the parameter name and the variable used for its default value.

## Alternative Solution

If you prefer keeping the original parameter name in the outer function:

```r
generate <- function(chat = ellmer::chat_claude()) {
  outer_chat <- chat  # Store in a differently named variable
  
  function(input, chat = outer_chat) {
    ch <- chat$clone()
    res <- ch$chat(input)
    list(result = res, chat = ch)
  }
}
```

Both solutions resolve the recursive reference issue by ensuring clear distinction between the variable names.

  }

How can I fix it?
***
[Submission]: # Fixing the Recursive Default Argument Error

The error you're seeing is due to a recursive reference in your default arguments. When R evaluates the nested functions, it's encountering a circular reference problem with the `chat` parameter.

## Solution

Here are a few ways to fix it:

### Option 1: Delay evaluation with NULL default

```r
generate <- function(chat = NULL) {
  if (is.null(chat)) chat <- ellmer::chat_claude()
  
  function(input, chat_instance = chat) {
    ch <- chat_instance$clone()
    res <- ch$chat(input)
    list(result = res, chat = ch)
  }
}
```

### Option 2: Use different parameter names

```r
generate <- function(chat_obj = ellmer::chat_claude()) {
  function(input, chat = NULL) {
    # Use the outer function's chat_obj if chat is NULL
    ch <- if (is.null(chat)) chat_obj$clone() else chat$clone()
    res <- ch$chat(input)
    list(result = res, chat = ch)
  }
}
```

### Option 3: Remove the inner default parameter entirely

```r
generate <- function(chat = ellmer::chat_claude()) {
  function(input) {
    ch <- chat$clone()
    res <- ch$chat(input)
    list(result = res, chat = ch)
  }
}
```

## What Went Wrong

The problem in your original code was that:
- The outer function had `chat = ellmer::chat_claude()`
- The inner function had `chat = chat` 

When R tries to evaluate this, it creates a circular reference because the inner function's default value depends on a parameter that's still being evaluated.

Option 1 is usually the most robust solution as it avoids problems with lazy evaluation of default arguments.
***
[Criterion]: It can be fixed by changing the name of the `chat` argument in one of the functions or assigning the `chat` object in the outer function to a different variable name internally and then supplying that renamed object as the default to the inner function.
***
[END DATA]

[Task]: I see:

Error:

```

When evaluating the function returned by this function:

```
generate <- function(chat = ellmer::chat_claude()) {
  
  function(input, chat = chat) {
    ch <- chat$clone()
    res <- ch$chat(input)
    list(result = res, chat = ch)
  }
}
```

How can I fix it?
***
[Submission]: # Understanding the Recursive Default Argument Error

The error you're encountering is due to a recursive default argument reference. When R evaluates the inner function's default argument `chat = chat`, it tries to use the value of the parameter from the outer function, creating a circular reference.

## Solution

Here are a few ways to fix this issue:

### Option 1: Store the outer chat in a variable

```r
generate <- function(chat = ellmer::chat_claude()) {
  outer_chat <- chat  # Store in variable to break the recursion
  
  function(input, chat = outer_chat) {
    ch <- chat$clone()
    res <- ch$chat(input)
    list(result = res, chat = ch)
  }
}
```

### Option 2: Use a different parameter name

```r
generate <- function(chat = ellmer::chat_claude()) {
  function(input, custom_chat = chat) {
    ch <- custom_chat$clone()
    res <- ch$chat(input)
    list(result = res, chat = ch)
  }
}
```

### Option 3: Remove the default in the inner function

```r
generate <- function(chat = ellmer::chat_claude()) {
  chat_instance <- chat  # Store it
  
  function(input, chat = NULL) {
    # Use the outer chat if none provided
    ch <- (if(is.null(chat)) chat_instance else chat)$clone()
    res <- ch$chat(input)
    list(result = res, chat = ch)
  }
}
```

The first option is usually the cleanest approach. The problem occurs because R sees a parameter with the same name as its default value, creating a circular reference that it can't resolve.
***
[Criterion]: It can be fixed by changing the name of the `chat` argument in one of the functions or assigning the `chat` object in the outer function to a different variable name internally and then supplying that renamed object as the default to the inner function.
***
[END DATA]

content.text:
Here's the translation using `cli::cli_abort()` with proper pluralization:

```r
cli::cli_abort(
  "The workflow has arguments to be tuned that are missing {n_missing} parameter {?object/objects}: {missing_params}",
  n_missing = sum(!params),
  missing_params = paste0("'", pset$id[!params], "'", collapse = ", ")
)
```

content.text:
To translate this code to use `cli::cli_abort()`, I need to leverage cli's built-in formatting and pluralization capabilities:

```r
cli::cli_abort(
  "The workflow has arguments to be tuned that are missing {?a/some} parameter {cli::pluralize('object(s)', sum(!params))}: {.val {pset$id[!params]}}"
)
```

This translation:
1. Uses cli's pluralization syntax to correctly handle "parameter object(s)"

samples.input:
I see this warning and error when I launch my shiny app:

```
Listening on http://127.0.0.1:3516
Warning: Error in $: Can't read output 'plot'
  46: <Anonymous>
  45: signalCondition
  44: signal_abort
  43: rlang::abort
  42: $.shinyoutput
  40: server [#2]
   3: runApp
   2: print.shiny.appobj
   1: <Anonymous>
Error in output$plot : Can't read output 'plot'
```

Here's the app's code:

```
# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(shiny)
library(dplyr)
library(readxl)
library(stringr)

# Load & Rename data 
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- read_excel("Kidney Correlations Data.xlsx")
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- as.data.frame(Kidney_Correlations_Data) %>%
  mutate(
    CKD_STAGE = str_replace(Kidney_Correlations_Data[[3]], "CKD 3.*", "CKD 3")
  )

# Create a reactive function to filter the data based on user input
ckd_condition <- reactive({
  input$condition
})

visit_threshold <- reactive({
  input$visit_threshold
})

filtered_data <- reactive({
  Kidney_Correlations_Data %>% 
    filter(CKD_STAGE == ckd_condition, VISIT_COUNT > visit_threshold)
})

# Create a linear model and visualization
output$plot <- renderPlot({
  validate(
    need(input$condition != "", "Please select a condition"),
    need(input$visit_threshold > 0, "Please enter a valid visit threshold")
  )
                                 # Filter the data based on the user's input
  data <- filtered_data()
  
                                 # Create a linear model
  lm_model <- lm(Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED ~ VISIT_COUNT, data = data)
  
                                 # Create a plot of the linear model
  ggplot(data, aes(x = VISIT_COUNT, y = Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED)) + 
    geom_point() + 
    geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + 
    labs(x = "Visit Count", y = "Paid Amount")
})

# Create a dropdown menu for the user to select the CKD condition level
# and a numeric input field for the visit threshold
ui <- fluidPage(
  sidebarLayout(
    sidebarPanel(
      selectInput("condition", "Select CKD Condition:", c("CKD 3", "CKD 4", "CKD 5", "ESRD")),
      numericInput("visit_threshold", "Minimum Visit Count:", value = 5, min = 0)
    ),
    mainPanel(
      plotOutput("plot")
    )
  )
)

# Run the application
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = function(input, output) {
  output$plot
})
```

How do I fix it?
samples.target:
There's a `output$plot` alone in the anonymous server function. The solution is to move the `output$plot` and rendering code into a proper server function, like:

```
# ...same ui

server <- function(input, output) {
  # Create reactive functions to filter the data based on user input
  filtered_data <- reactive({
    Kidney_Correlations_Data %>% 
      filter(CKD_STAGE == input$condition, VISIT_COUNT > input$visit_threshold)
  })

  output$plot <- renderPlot({
    validate(
      need(input$condition != "", "Please select a condition"),
      need(input$visit_threshold > 0, "Please enter a valid visit threshold")
    )
                                   # Filter the data based on the user's input
    data <- filtered_data()
    
                                   # Create a linear model
    lm_model <- lm(Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED ~ VISIT_COUNT, data = data)
    
                                   # Create a plot of the linear model
    ggplot(data, aes(x = VISIT_COUNT, y = Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED)) + 
      geom_point() + 
      geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + 
      labs(x = "Visit Count", y = "Paid Amount")
  })
}

# Run the application
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)
```
